screen.Content:
You are carrying out this course because as part of your daily role you have responsibility for dealing with financial information. You should therefore be versed in the principles of basic financial management and budgeting.

Should you have accessibility issues all text can be read by a screen reader and text is vocalised by the presenter or voiceover in most cases.

screen_id.keywords: Work, Sky, City, Skyline, Building, Board, White, Presentation

screen.Content:
Welcome to this learning resource on Financial Management and Budgeting. This course covers the following issues:

• Financial Management

• Financial Terminology

• Budgeting for Business

The course will last 45 minutes and there will be a quiz at the end to test your knowledge.
The viability of a company financially is its ability to create income which covers its expenses and costs plus have a chance to invest in development and growth.
Being able to demonstrate the performance and financial position is essential for companies to stakeholders, staff and investors.

screen_id.keywords: Help, Desk, Person, Consultation, Advice, Silhouette, Office, Work

screen.Content:
Questions to Assess Financial Viability

Even those with many years of experience running a business can often lose track of whether a business idea or business itself is financially viable. Various questions should be asked when examining financial viability ...
How heavily does the business have to borrow?
Does the business repay loans in time?
Does the business have systems in place to account for unexpected events?
Can the business support its needs?
If the business is not profitable is there a plan to change this?
Is the business performing better of worse than it had in the past?
How long could the business function while making a loss?

Even those with many years of experience running a business can find themselves needing support once there has been considerable growth, movement to a different sector or changes to regulations and law.

In these circumstances it is common to look to get support from a professional advisor; click for options available to you ...

Accountants

Provide help with running office books (accounts) and compliances with taxes.

Can generate predictions of finances to use with investor presentations.

Bankers

Help with loan applications and facilitation.

Hold on to cashflow and provide interest of savings.

Provide money management and investor options.

Solicitors and Lawyers

Provide legal advice on financial matters such as contracts.

Disputes with suppliers / customers.

Reclaiming funds over intellectual property and debts.

Insurance Brokers

Support with coping with risk.

Lodging claims on the business's behalf.

Management Consultants

Advise on Human Resource issues.

Training costs and benefits.

Making operations as effective as possible.

It should be no surprise that bad financial planning is the main cause of business failure. A business can be making a profit but not looking far enough ahead to deal with any problems it could face and therefore face closure should this happen.

Another business could regularly make a small loss but as a result of future planning actually be better equipped to survive in difficult periods. Financial viability is not always about a business turning over a large profit.

To expand or develop a business there are two main methods, borrowing or using profits. The risks of borrowing to expand can be that debt payments are missed if income from the growth is lower than expected. However, some businesses might not generate enough profit to facilitate a large change that is needed. This is why a comprehensive financial forecast is worthwhile before committing to changes.
A business could grow too quickly for its means, an environmental or governmental change or a revolutionary technological development can all cause financial difficulties for an organisation.

Example 1: Woolworths

A very large British retailer that was forced to close down from 2009, the business was hit by reduced spending following the start of a recession.

The company did not follow the trend of having non-high street locations and lost out to retail park trading. Neither did it account for the growth in digital music sales - it used CDs as a large part of its store space. The problem was exacerbated by supermarkets, which started selling the items that Woolworths had specialised in.

Example 2: Polaroid

Highly successful instant photo company. Almost had a monopoly on the industry and started a process of stagnation in product development.

The development of digital cameras and smartphones made Polaroid technology outdated. Poor planning had left the company too low on funds to adapt an rebrand before closing in 2005.

Example 3: Zynga

Created Farmville and other popular games played through Facebook. Expanded quickly following Farmville's success. Buying multiple offices and enlarging the workforce.

Due to the changing trends in social media Zynga lost 40% of its users and as a result lost investor money too. Further drops in revenue, deals ending with Facebook and bad customer perception meant more closures and redundancies. Still trading but at a greatly restricted level.

In any area of expertise there is a language used and specific terminology that can seem impenetrable to those unfamiliar with the subject. Finance, budgeting and accounting are no different and it can help to prepare by researching some of these terms before meeting with advisors or experts.

Accrual

Accumulation of funds through interest or by combining investments. It can be from monies not yet received.

Asset

Anything owned by an organisation that has an economic value. Tangible assets are items, physical things. Intangible assets are customer goodwill, copyrights, patents, bonds and stocks.

Audit

The examination of the financial records of an organisation. It is a method of checking a firm is working within the law financially.

Balance Sheet

One of the key financial statements an organisation might have to produce. Assets, liabilities and equity are listed and provide a overview of a company's financial position.

Break-even

The threshold where a company moves from making a loss to making a profit. The point at which expenditure is recouped.

Budget

The amount of money that an organisation is planning to spend. A budget can cover an entire organisation, a project or event.

Capital Gain

The amount of money made when selling an asset from the original cost. It is a value that tax is often paid from.

Cash Flow

The total amount of money coming in or being spent on a daily basis by an organisation.

Creditor

The person/organisation to whom money is owed from a debt.

Current Liabilities

The money owed by an organisation, often measured in 12 month periods.

Debtor

A person or organisation that owes another money.

Depreciation

The loss of value of an asset over time.

Dividend

A payment made by an organisation to its shareholders. Usually based on profits.

Equity

The value of an organisation's assets once their liability is taken away.

Gross Profit / Loss

The money made or lost from sales after just the costs and expenditure is subtracted.

Liabilities

What the business owes. Often long term loans used in setting a business up or launching a new project.

National Insurance

A state run social security scheme that is compulsory for all organisations. Provides state benefits and healthcare.

Net Profit / Loss

The profit or loss after all the organisation’s deductions are taken off. Differs from gross which will only account for the cost of the raw materials and production.

Budgets can vary massively in scope and size. Breaking them into three categories is an easy way to ensure a better understanding of how a budget is managed and controlled.

For example, when the Chancellor of the Exchequer announces where and what the government is spending, saving and taxing - it is called “the Budget”. All organisations will have to do the same thing to run efficiently – albeit on a smaller scale.

screen_id.keywords: Silhouettes, Page, Document, Paper, Thinking, List

screen.Content:
Master Budgets

This is usually the annual account of every bit of spending an organisation will incur. It will line up with the financial year of April to March or September to August for the education sector and will be divided into quarters or terms. The size of this task means that this budget will be overseen by a specialist team or even an external specialist.

This budget is frequently divided into the Capital Budget and the Operational Budget.

Capital Budgets

This budgeting decides whether or not an investment or piece of expenditure is worthwhile for a business or organisation. It could be buying new equipment for an office or facility, recruiting new staff or research and development expenditure.

Some of the techniques for doing this are:

Payback Period – working out the time needed to recoup the money to break even.

Net Present Value – takes the present values of the outflowing cash from the projected value of cash over a period of time. This method takes into account the inflation or deflation of a currency.

Internal Rate of Return – this presents the percentage of profit against expenditure without accounting for external influences.

There are many more ways to calculate a Capital Budget, some might be industry specific or factor in recent legal or environmental changes.

Organisations will use several at once, particularly for investments that carry a high level of risk.

Operating Budgets

This budget contains the estimates for the value of resources needed for an organisation to continue operating at its current or at a higher standard. This budget factors in expenditure on salaries, maintenance and interest payments.

This is the budget that helps an organisation present its accounts at the end of the financial year and a framework around which it can function in over the next 12 months. They will take into account historical data, realistic estimates of future expenditure and inflation/deflation. For ease of feedback and monitoring operating budgets need to be presented very clearly and methodically.

screen_id.keywords: Slideshow, Video, Screen, Laptop, Ultrabook, PC, Computer, HD Video, Presentation

screen.Content:
Once a budget is completed it should be considered a working document, i.e. one that is continually adapted and developed as needed.

Recessions, market changes, environmental issues and fluctuations in public perception and currency value can all affect the figures in a budget.
Monitoring the budget can reduce the chances of it becoming obsolete. The key aspects of the budget that need to be closely checked at regular intervals are income and expenditure.

Income

With respect to income, this needs to be regularly compared with the current actual income. It is important that reasons for any shortfall are examined, factoring in aspects such as seasonal changes, interest rates etc.

Expenditure

Fixed costs should be checked for variance from the budget as well as the potentially variable ones. Look over the variable costs relative to the income. Consider factors such as have all suppliers’ costs been considered in the budget etc.

A variance is the difference between the expected budget and the actual budget used. There are two outcomes:

Positive – the budget expenditure was less or the money made was more.
Adverse – the costs were higher than expected or less money was made

It is acceptable to have some variance as an estimated budget is just that, an estimate, a guess. However, careful planning and budget monitoring is what protects against a large variation in figures.

Using previous records as reference points will add to the safety in these estimations. If there is a worry of a large amount of variance, it is recommended to redo the original budget and re-present it to the investors.

screen.Content: Complete the quiz before continuing.

settings.Retake_Test: You have reached the end of the test.
settings.No_Issues: You have got 100%, no further action is required.
settings.Few_Issues: You have got very few questions wrong, there is no cause for immediate concern.
settings.Some_Issues: You have got some answers wrong, you may wish to retake the test.
settings.Many_Issues: You have got many questions wrong, we strongly recommend you redo the training.

Well done you have completed the course in Financial Management and Budgeting. You should now know the basics concerning:

• Financial Management

• Financial Terminology

• Budgeting for Business
